Paracetamol Toxicity:
{{c1::50%}} Accidental Overdose ,{{c1::50%}} suicide

Paracetamol toxicity is a common cause of {{c1::fulminant hepatic failure}}

Dose: 
 Toxicity unlikely < {{c1::10g}} in adults 
 Toxicity almost universal > {{c1::20g}} in adults 
 1 Panadol tablet = 500mg paracetamol
this is the new and improved nomogram

Clinical Features of Paracetamol Intoxication:

First 24 hours 
 {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting
 Malaise 
 Labs results are {{c1::normal}} 

24-72 hours 
 Elevated 
   -{{c1::aminotransferase}}: Due to degradation of hepatocytes
   -{{c1::bilirubin}}: Due to degradation of hemoglobin
   -{{c1::prothrombin time}}: Due to absence of clotting factors             2,7,9,10
 RUQ pain 
 {{c1::Renal}} failure

72-96 hours 
 {{c1::Jaundice}}: Due to build u of bilirubin 
 {{c1::Encephalopathy}}: Due to liver not working anymore
 Worsening liver and renal function

 > 96 hours 
 Death 
 Liver transplant 
 Slow recovery
Serum Creatinine can be an indicator of renal failure

Treatment of paracetamol intoxication:

Gastrointestinal decontamination: 
{{c1::Activated charcoal}} (adsorbing agent)
If < {{c1::4}} hours since ingestion 
Longer if delayed-release tabs used 

Antidotes
Drug Name: {{c1::N-acetylcysteine}} 
 Precursor of {{c1::glutathione}} 
 Increases {{c1::glutathione}} stores 
 Neutralizes {{c1::NAPQI}} 
 Anti-{{c1::inflammatory}} & anti-{{c1::oxidant}} properties 
 Highly efficacious

Indications for NAC

-Serum paracetamol concentration drawn at 4 hours or more after a single acute ingestion is above the "possible hepatic toxicity" line of the Rumack-Matthew nomogram

-Serum paracetamol concentration is unavailable or will not return within {{c1::8}} hours of time of ingestion and paracetamol ingestion suspected

-{{c1::Time}} of ingestion is unknown and serum paracetamol level is greater than {{c1::10}} micrograms/ml

-There is evidence of ANY {{c1::hepatotoxicity}} with a history of paracetamol ingestion

-Patient reports or clinician suspects {{c1::repeated}} excessive paracetamol ingestions, patient has risk factors for paracetamol -induced hepatotoxicity, and the serum paracetamol level is greater than 10 micrograms/mL
New nomogram, and you use treatment line now, which is 25% lower than possible hepatic toxicity line.

N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI) 
 Highly {{c1::reactive}} electrophile 
 Covalently binds {{c1::hepatocyte}} macromolecules. Covalent means bond is {{c1::Irreversible}}
 Can cause {{c1::Oxidative}} injury 
 {{c1::Centrilobular}} necrosis 
 Secondary release of {{c1::cytokines}} and {{c1::ROS}}

Where is the best ventilation in the lung? Apex/Base  {{c1::Base}}
Where is the best perfusion in the lung? APex/Base {{c1::Base}}

Measurement of regional differences in ventilation is measured using {{c1::radioactive xenon}} (substance marker)

Pulmonary blood flow is much higher at base/apex due to {{c1::gravity}}         {{c1::base}}

Zone 1 (APEX OF LUNG)
• {{c1::Alveolar}} pressure higher than {{c1::Pulmonary artery}} Pressure & {{c1::venous}} Pressure, so collapsible vessels closed and no flow

• Zone 2 (middle of lung)
• {{c1::Pulmonary artery}} pressure > {{c1::Alveolar }} pressure > {{c1::venous}} pressure. 
Constriction at the downstream end of collapsible vessel.
Intermittent flow with each breath

• Zone 3
• (Pulmonary artery) pressure > (venous) pressure > (Alveolar) pressure , and so collapsible vessels are held open
From the Apex to base of the lung ventilation decreases {{c1::less}} quickly than perfusion

{{c1::Deadspace}} : High ventilation, low perfusion
{{c1::Shunt}}:  Low ventilation, high perfusion

Shunt and deadspace can lead to hypoxia
Shunt
• Perfusion of lung units without ventilation
• Unoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation
• V/Q = 0

• Dead space
• Ventilation of lung units without perfusion
• Gas enters and leaves lung units without contacting blood
• Wasted ventilation
• V/Q is infinite

Flow= Pressure{{c1::/}} Resistance

At low flow rates, flow is {{c1::laminar}}
At higher flow rates (esp. at branches etc.) flow is {{c1::turbulent}}

Most resistance (and turbulent flow) is in {{c1::medium}} sized bronchi 
{{c1::Terminal}} bronchioles offer very little resistance

In upper airway obstruction, development of {{c1::turbulent}} flow is important mechanism of increased airway resistance
 
Treated by {{c1::Heliox}} (21 % O2 , 79 % He) 
{{c1::Less}} dense than air so more conducive to laminar flow and ↓ resistance in turbulent flow


Factors Affecting Airway Resistance 
• Lung Volume:

Increased Lung volume= {{c1::decreased}} Airway resistance and {{c1::increased}} Bronchi diameter  

Decreased Lung volume= {{c1::increased}} Airway resistance 
Small airways (base of lung) may close completely 


Factors Affecting Airway Resistance 
• Bronchial smooth muscle contraction ↓ airway diameter ↑ resistance 
 Due to {{c1::Vagus}}nerve and {{c1::ACh}} (NT) and Irritant reflexes 

• Bronchial smooth muscle relaxation ↑ airway diameter ↓ resistance
 • Activation of {{c1::adrenergic}} receptors

Oxygen delivery
DO2 = CO {{c1::x}} CaO2

CaO2=Oxygen content of arterial blood

CaO2 =({{c1::Hb}} x 1.34 x SaO2/100) + 0.0225 PaO2 (Kpa)

RENIN-ANGIOTENSIN SYSTEM:

{{c1::Angiotensinogen}} converted by {{c1::Renin}} (made in {{c1::kidneys}}) to {{c1::Angiotensin 1}}, convertd by {{c1::ACE}} (found in {{c1::lungs}}) to {{c1::Angiotensin 2}}

–{{c1::Decreased}} pressure at the {{c1::afferent}} arteriole
- Sympathetic activation (beta1)

Both happen during {{c1::hypovolaemia}}

Effects of angiotensin II

– Arteriolar {{c1::vasoconstriction}}
(hence ↑ {{c1::MAP}}) and decreased {{c1::GFR}}

– Stimulation of {{c1::aldosterone}} secretion
(hence ↑ {{c1::plasma volume}})

– Na+ {{c1::reabsorption}} by the {{c1::proximal tubule}}


– Thirst ({{c1::subfornical organ}})

When intravascular volume is {{c1::low}}, the renin-angiotensin (and aldosterone) system is activated.

This helps to:
1. {{c1::maintain blood pressure}}
2. {{c1::retain volume}}

Circulatory Shock

The state in which profound and widespread reduction in the delivery of {{c1::02}} and other {{c1::nutrients}} to {{c1::tissues}}, leads firstly to {{c1::reversible}} and, if {{c1::prolonged}}, leads to irreversible cellular injury.

Caused By
1. {{c1::reduced blood volume (hypovolaemic shock)}}
2. {{c1::loss of cardiac function (cardiogenic shock)}}
3. {{c1::loss of the ability to maintain an adequate total peripheral resistance (distributive shock)}}

Decrease in blood volume following haemorrhage causes a fall in {{c1::MABP}}

{{c1::MABP}} = CO x TPR

A fall in {{c1::MABP}} following haemorrhage elicits homeostatic reflexes to minimise the fall in {{c1::MABP}}
• 3 responses

- Immediate: {{c1::Baroceptor reflex}}

- Intermediate: {{c1::Borrows fluid from the interstitial space}}

- Long-term: {{c1::Replaces fluid, plasma proteins and rbcs}}

SHORT TERM
- A haemorrhage causes a drop in arterial pressure
- BP drop detected by {{c1::reduced firing of baroceptors}}

Effect on HEART:
-{{c1::decreased}} parasympathetic cardiac activity
-{{c1::increased}} sympathetic cardiac activity
Change in both ps and s activity leads to {{c1::Increased firing of SA node to increase heart rate}}
Change in specifically sypathetic activity causes increased {{c1::cardiac muscle contractility}} which leads to an increase in {{c1::stroke volume}}.

Both Mechanisms contribute to increasing {{c1::Cardiac Output}}

Effect on VEINS:
-{{c1::increased}} sympathetic venous activity
Peripheral Veno{{c1::constriction}} which causes:
{{c1::Increased}} Venous Pressure
{{c1::Increased}} Venous return
{{c1::Increased}} EDV


Which leads to an increased {{c1::Stroke Volume}} and {{c1::Cardiac Output}}

Effects on Arteries:
Ateroconstriction ------- Increased TPR

Intermediate

The reduction in {{c1::capillary hydrostatic}} pressure favours the movement of fluid from the {{c1::interstitial}} into the {{c1::vascular space}}

• As a result, {{c1::plasma volume}} is increased (back to normal in 12 to 24 hr)
• {{c1::MABP}} is restored towards normal (blood loss up to 1L - 20% of TBV)

Fluid replacement

Following haemorrhage, the hormone {{c1::aldosterone}} is released from the adrenal cortex

{{c1::Aldosterone}} stimulates the retention of {{c1::Na+ (and water)}} by the kidneys

Following haemorrhage, {{c1::thirst}} is stimulated. {{c1::Ingestion of water}} will replace the fluid lost during the haemorrhage


Following haemorrhage, the {{c1::bone marrow}} is stimulated to
produce {{c1::red blood}} cells

Replacement of {{c1::red blood}} cells lost during the haemorrhage may take {{c1::3-4 weeks}}

Blood losses up to {{c1::20% (1L)}} can be compensated for

Hypovolaemic shock (blood loss)

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage of up to 10% of total blood volume: {{c1::fully compensated}}
• CO is {{c1::maintained}}
• MABP is {{c1::maintained}}
• PP is {{c1::maintained}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 10% and 20% of total blood volume: compensated shock
• CO {{c1::falls (reduced circulating BV)}}
• MABP is {{c1::maintained by increased TPR}}
• Pulse pressure (PP) is {{c1::reduced}}

{{c1::Cerebral (brain)}} and {{c1::coronary blood flow (heart)}} are 1initially protected from the fall in MAP (MAP>{{c1::70mmHg}})

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 20% and 30% of total blood volume
• CO {{c1::continues to fall}}
• MABP {{c1::falls}}
• PP is {{c1::not there}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 30% and 40% of total blood volume

• CO continues to fall
• MABP extremely low
• At about {{c1::35%}} loss of BV, MAP plateaus
- hypoxia in {{c1::brain}}
- direct stimulation of {{c1::cardiovascular centres}}
- massive{{c1::sympathetic stimulation}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage above 40% of total blood volume

{{c1::Complete collapse of CVS}}

A. Progressive shock: the vicious cycle

Once haemorrhage is severe enough (and no fluid replacement is performed)
- {{c1::coronary blood flow}} falls
- reduced {{c1::coronary blood flow}} reduces myocardial {{c1::contractility}}
- reduced {{c1::cardiac output}}
- reduced {{c1::MAP}} leads to a reduction in coronary blood flow VICIOUS CYCLE
• As the shock is becoming worse at this time, it is said to be progessive stage of shock

If hypovolaemic shock remains untreated, {{c1::myocardial contractility}} falls (hypoxia)
• By {{c1::4}} hr, the Starling curve is
poor
• By {{c1::5}} hr, the Starling curve
cannot maintain life

B. Irreversible shock:

If fluid replacement is not performed in severe haemorrhage, the progressive stage of shock will soon progress into irreversible shock

• When the patient enters irreversible shock, fluid administration or other therapy is {{c1::incapable}} of saving the patient
• Initially, fluid administration will {{c1::elevate}} cardiac output during the fluid administration and for a short period afterwards
• Unfortunately, {{c1::permanent}} damage to the {{c1::tissue of the heart (reduced contractility)}} and {{c1::brain (including the cardiovascular centre in the medulla)}} is likely to have occurred
• The patient can neither control {{c1::myocardial contractility}} (reduced CO) or {{c1::vascular tone(TPR)}} and consequently {{c1::MAP}} cannot be maintained

Blood Movement Recap:
• Blood enters the aorta from the left ventricle at high velocity: up to {{c1::1.5 –2.0}} m/s ({{c1::600}} ml/s) - mean velocity: {{c1::0.20}} m/s 

• About {{c1::2}}/3 of the stroke volume is ejected during the first {{c1::1}}/3 of systole 

• The {{c1::aorta}} stretches during systole to accommodate 70-80% of stroke volume 

• The other 20-30% of SV flows into the {{c1::peripheral vessels}}

• Peak in aortic pressure (systolic pressure) occurs {{c1::later}} than peak aortic blood flow - this is due to the elastic stretching of the aorta 

• Following closure of the {{c1::aortic}} valve, a short back-flow occurs Which is detectable on the pressure trace as an incisura known as the {{c1::dicrotic notch}}

• Blood flows from the arteries, through the arterioles (resistances) throughout diastole, reaching the minimum pressure (diastolic pressure) just before the next cardiac cycle 

• Diastolic pressure never falls to 0 mmHg due to {{c1::TPR}}

The maximum to which arterial pressure rises is called {{c1::systolic pressure}}. normal range? {{c1::110-129}} mmHg

the minimum to which it falls is called {{c1::diastolic pressure}}. normal range? {{c1::70-84}} mmHg

What state is an adult in if their bp is normal? {{c1::normotensive state}}

Blood pressure {{c1::dips}} during the night
What does it mean if this doesn't happen?{{c1::usually hypertension}}

Systolic pressure {{c1::rises}} with age due to reducing {{c1::compliance}}

• What happens to diastolic pressure with age? {{c1::increases until 50 and then falls}}

• Mean arterial pressure increases moderately with age due to a rise in {{c1::TPR}}

• Clinical hypertension: {{c1::chronic, usually progressive, raised arterial pressure}}

Most physicians diagnose hypertension if repeated measurements of resting pressure:
exceed {{c1::140/90}} mmHg in a patient under 50 years old 
exceed {{c1::160/95}} mmHg in a patient over 50 years old

Peripheral vasoconstriction  (essential hypertension)

• {{c1::a}}-Adrenoceptor mediated peripheral vasoconstriction may initially be reversed by vasodilators 

• Persistent {{c1::a}}-adrenoceptor mediated peripheral vasoconstriction causes {{c1::hypertrophy}} of the walls of small arteries/arterioles, {{c1::narrowing}} of the vessels and elevated resistance which cannot be {{c1::reversed}} by vasodilators (TPR remains elevated)
 
• The elevated blood pressure can reduce the number of small arteries/arterioles in a process called rarefaction (further increase in TPR)

Hypertension itself is virtually symptomless

 • Contrary to popular belief, it rarely presents with nose bleeds or headaches!

 • If not treated, hypertension damages the heart, brain and kidneys, leading to:
§ cardiac hypertrophy:{{c1::abnormal enlargement, or thickening, of the heart muscle}}
§ hypertensive heart failure 
§ atheromatous coronary artery disease ; {{c1::build-up of fatty deposits (atheroma) on the walls of the arteries around the heart (coronary arteries)}}

§ chronic renal failure

Ventricular hypertrophy 
Cardiac hypertrophy occurs in response to increased {{c1::afterload}} (increased arterial pressure - hypertension) 
• The heart has to perform more work to eject blood against the increase {{c1::afterload }}
• The walls of the heart grow thicker (hypertrophy) 
• Specifically concentric hypertrophy: {{c1::The wall grows thicker without an increase in chamber size}} 
• The ventricular wall becomes {{c1::stiffer}} (loss of distensibility) 
• Ventricular {{c1::relaxation}} becomes impaired 
• {{c1::Diastolic filling}} of the ventricle is reduced 
• Why doesn't this happento endurance athletes? {{c1::In endurance athletes the cardiac hypertrophy is accompanied by an increased chamber size}}

Chronic elevation of arterial pressure causes left ventricular hypertrophy (wall grows thicker) 


-{{c1::AngII}} and {{c1::Endothelin}} trigger a kinase pathway called MAPkinase
-{{c1::nuclear transcription}} factors are activated 
-hypertrophy genes are activated and the wall grows thicker 

• The hypertrophy helps the heart deal with the persistent high afterload (hypertension), at least for a while 

• The high cardiac work performed by the hypertrophic heart, makes it susceptible to {{c1::ischaemia}} and {{c1::heart failure}} (see later)

ECG and LVH

In LVH the left ventricle enlarges.

So the leads oriented to the left ventricle ({{c1::V5, V6, aVL}}(3)) will "see" more electrical activity moving towards them. 

The leads oriented away from the left ventricle {{c1::(V1, V2)}}(2) will "see" more activity moving away from them. 

Leads {{c1::V5, V6 and aVL}}(3) will have tall R waves

Leads {{c1::V1 and V2}}(2) will have deep S waves. 

What is the voltage criteria for LVH?
{{c1::The voltage criteria for LVH are satisfied if the sum of the amplitude of the deepest S wave in V1 or V2, and the amplitude of the tallest R wave in V5 or V6, is equal to or greater than 35 mm (3.5 mV). The voltage criteria are also satisfied if the amplitude of the R wave in lead aVL is equal to or greater than 12 mm (1.2mV)}}

• The myocardium is composed of {{c1::cardiac myoctyes}} (cardiac muscle cells) and {{c1::extracellular matrix }}

• When the myocardium undergoes hypertrophy, the {{c1::myocyte}} increases in size - more by increase diameter than length 

• During development of hypertrophy the number and diameter of {{c1::capillaries}} remains unchanged 

• The distance between {{c1::capillaries}} increases 

• The ratio of {{c1::capillary}} surface area to {{c1::myocyte}} volume decreases 

• Less O2 for {{c1::myocyte}} metabolism

Course of hypertension and therapeutic strategies 
• Untreated the outlook for hypertensives is grave, with 
§ ~50% of patients eventually developing {{c1::heart}} failure 
§ ~25% of patients eventually developing {{c1::renal}} failure 
§ ~25% eventually developing {{c1::cerebral}} complications ({{c1::eg, retinopathy, strokes}}) 

• It is important, therefore, to treat hypertension at the symptomless stage

• The aim of the therapy for hypertension: 
- is to reduce systolic pressure to {{c1::135-145}} mmHg 
and diastolic pressure to {{c1::85}} mmHg.
 - this greatly reduces the mortality and morbidity


There are four main therapeutic avenues: Match 'em Up
1.Reduction of TPR (MAP = CO x TPR) 

2. Reduction of the extracellular fluid volume (which is elevated in hypertension) and hence blood pressure 

3.• Inhibition angiotensin-converting enzyme to reduce angiotensin II and aldosterone 

4.Reduction of cardiac output and hence blood pressure (MAP = CO x TPR)

a. Diuretic Drugs{{c1::2}}
b.ACE-inhibitors{{c1::3}}
c. Calcium channel blockers and a1-adrenoceptor blockers{{c1::1}}
d. Beta-blockers{{c1::4}}

Give examples for all except Diretic drugs

calcium-channel blockers (nifedipine) and a1-adrenoreceptor blockers (prazosin)
Captopril blocks the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE-inhibitor
b-adrenoceptor blockers such as propranolol and atenolol

Reasons For Ischaemic Contractile Failure:

1. Reduction in ATP and CP formation, why? {{c1::can only do anaerobic resp in ischemic cells}} why is this bad?{{c1::energy is needed for contractility}}

2. Build-up of lactate, why?{{c1::again,anaerobic resp}} and why is this bad? {{c1::. Lactate make the cell acidic which reduces actin:myosin crossbridge cycling (reduced contractility)}}

3. Opening of ATP-sensitive {{c1::K+}} channels

Effect of high extracellular potassium on the cardiac action potential:

Extracellular potassium is due to {{c1::the opening of ATP linked channels}}

The normal potassium concentration in extracellular fluid is {{c1::3.5-5.5}} mM 

• A concentration of {{c1::7.5}} mM will arrest the heart in diastole

The {{c1::resting membrane potential}} for the surrounding cells becomes more positive

Fast Na+ channels are voltage sensitive

 • Following depolarisation, they are “inexcitable” until the cell is repolarised

 • If the resting membrane potential is more positive than normal i.e. cell isn't fully repolarised, what happens? {{c1::only a portion of the channels will change from the “inexcitable” to the “excitable” stat}}

 • During the next depolarisation, fewer fast channels will be opened

 • The {{c1::slope}} and {{c1::amplitude}} of the upstroke of the AP are reduced

Also K+ channels are always open so {{c1::the plateau}} phase stops and thus AP becomes {{c1::shorter}}

Ventricle drops to a lower starling curve

At b 
CO down to {{c1::2}} l/min 
• {{c1::EDV}} increased 
• RAP up to {{c1::4}} mmHg

At C
{{c1::Increased}} contractility 
• Higher Starling curve 
• RAP {{c1::5}}mmHg 
• CO {{c1::4.2}} l/min
How? {{c1::Increased adrenergic activity with vasoconstriction leading to increase TPR}}
Long or Short term solution?{{c1::short}}

At D
Measurements at C maintained by activation of {{c1::the reninangiotensin-aldosterone}} system

Which increases {{c1::plasma }} volume and thus {{c1::cardiac output}}

However also causes rise in {{c1::EDV}}

What systems is blood flow reduced to during cardiac failure? {{c1::renal, GIT and skin}}(3)

ECGs and MI's

Following a myocardial infarction (heart attack) the {{c1::ST}} segment is elevated

Normal tissue 
• All tissue depolarizes and repolarizes together 
• No abnormal currents flow Normal tissue 

Ischaemic tissue 
• During diastole is ischaemic tissue more, positively, negatively or charged the same as normal tissue?{{c1::positively}}

• During mid- to late systole,ischaemic tissue more, positively, negatively or charged the same as normal tissue? {{c1::negatively}} 

• When different areas are tissue in the heart demonstrate a charge difference, an {{c1::abnormal}} current will flow
 • This is called {{c1::Current of injury}}

• During diastole 
• the ischaemic tissue is more {{c1::positive}} than the normal areas 
• a current of injury flows from the {{c1::ischaemic}} to the {{c1::normal}} tissue, away the detecting electrode 
• the major ECG change is depression of the {{c1::baseline (T-Q segment)}}

During midsystole 
• the normal tissue is more {{c1::positive}} than the ischaemic areas 
• a current of injury flows from the {{c1::normal}} to the {{c1::ischaemic}} tissue, towards the detecting electrode 
• the major ECG change is elevation of the {{c1::S-T segment}}



During mid-systole 
 • If the ischaemic area is {{c1::subendocardial}}, the current of injury is away from the detecting electrode 
• the major ECG change is depression of the S-T segment

ST segment elevation: current of injury from normal to ischaemic tissue {{c1::towards}} the detecting electrode

ST segment depression: current of injury from normal to ischaemic tissue {{c1::away}} from the detecting electrode

Which leads show 
(i) ST segment elevation? {{c1::3,2,aVF}}
(ii) ST segment depression? {{c1::aVL,1}}
(iii) No change?{{c1::aVR}}

Heart Failure is the inability of the heart to:
-{{c1::to pump blood at a sufficient cardiac output}}
-{{c1::to maintain adequate perfusion of other organs}}

Cardiomyopathy:{{c1::Any pathological process affecting the myocardium which results in a disturbance in myocardial function}}

Heart Failure can be:
-Sytolic dysfunction which indicates {{c1::Reduced Contractility}} 
-Diastolic dysfunction which indicates {{c1::Impaired Relaxation & Increased Stiffness}} (2)

Heart Failure is the result
Cardiomyopathy is the process

Ejection Fraction:{{c1::% emptying of the left ventricle}}

A measure of {{c1::systolic}} function

What is a normal ejection fraction?{{c1::55-60}}%

What is typically used to measure it? {{c1::Echocardiogram or MRI}}

What are the two types of heart failure with regards to EF?
-{{c1::Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF)}}
-{{c1::Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF)}}

Assuming you know both, what type of heart failure are these effects assocaited with

Reduced Stroke volume at rest and with exercise – Reduced “forward pressure” {{c1::both}}
• Increased intracardiac pressure – Increased “back pressure”{{c1::both}}

Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF) is same as diastolic dysfunction

eart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF) is same as systolic dysfunction
Determinants of Stroke Volume {{c1::1. Preload 2. Afterload 3. Contractility}} (3)

True or false

Higher Afterload= higher CO{{c::f}}

{{c1::• Reduced “forward-pressure” }}
{{c1::• Reduced organ perfusion }}

{{c1::• Increased “back-pressure” }}
{{c1::• Fluid retention – effect on the oncotic pressure}}

Neuro-hormonal Response to HF:
Compensatory Systems
1.What branch of the nervous system is triggered?{{c1::Sympathetic}}

It is activated by,
-Stimulation of {{c1::baroreceptors}}
-Renal {{c1::hypoperfusion}}

What are its three efects to counter heart failure
Increased {{c1::heart rate}}
Increased {{c1::Contractility}}
{{c1::Vasoconstriction}}

2.What hormonal system is triggered? {{c1::RAAS}}

It is activated by ,
-Stimulation of {{c1::beta adrenergic receptors}}
-Renal {{c1::hypoperfusion}}

What are its three efects to counter heart failure?
{{c1::vasoconstriction}}
Increased {{c1::glomerular filtration}}
{{c1::Sodium retention causing fluid retention}}

Adverse Affects of Compensatory Mechanisms:

1. Increase Heart Rate – {{c1::increases myocardial work }}
2. Increased contractility – {{c1::increases myocardial work}} 
3. Vasoconstriction – {{c1::increases afterload – increases myocardial work }}
4. Fluid retention – {{c1::volume overload}}

Eventually leads to adverse Left Ventricular Remodelling as demonstrated by {{c1::Laplace's}} Law
-LV {{c1::dilation}}
-Increased {{c1::intramural}} pressure
-LV becomes more {{c1::spherical}} (shape)

Heart Progressively Gets Bigger

can lead to pulmonary {{c1::oedema}} and {{c1::cardiogenic}} shock

In mild cardiac failure, {{c1::stroke volume}} may be almost normal due to a compensatory increase in {{c1::enddiastolic volume}}

Explain Compensated Heart Failure:{{c1::At rest stroke volume is normal, decompensated would be when stroke volume is below normal}}

Why isn't stroke volume or cardiac output always a good indicator of heart failure? {{c1::in compensated heart failure they can be almost normal}}

What is a more useful indicator {{c1::ejection fraction}}
What is its formula:{{c1::Ejection fraction (%) = SV/EDV}}
What is the normal measure of this indicator in the body? {{c1::55-70}}%

Excercise In a Normal Heart:

- {{c1::increased}} O2 consumption in exercising muscle
 • release of metabolic {{c1::vasodilators}}
 • reduced resistance in feed blood vessels
 • increased {{c1::muscle}} blood flow
 • reduced {{c1::TPR}}
 • increased central venous pressure, Why? {{c1::Less TPR means more blood goes into the venous system faster= more venous blood}}
 • {{c1::increased}} venous return
 • {{c1::increased}} ventricular EDV
 • {{c1::increase}} SV

Sympathetic Nervous system is also activated, explain how.{{1::adrenaline release, acts on cardiac b1 adrenoceptors}}

{{c1::Increases}} EF form c.60% to {{c1::80}}%

Excercise in Cardiac Failure:

• {{c1::increased}} ventricular EDV
• {{c1::increase}} SV

Is this the same as in Normal heart?
{{c1::yes}}

{{c1::decreases}} EF form c.60% to {{c1::45}}%

Why?{{c1::EDV needs to increase a lot more than in normal heart to achive same stroke volume}}

Is there sympathetic activity in excercise with heart failure? {{c1::no}} why?{{c1::Down-regulation of b1- adrenoceptors in the myocardial cells occurs}}

Healthy during exercise
• CO: rises {{c1::300}}%
 • SV: rises ({{c1::80}} to {{c1::100}} mL)
 • EF: rises ({{c1::66}}% to ~{{c1::80}}%)
 • EDV rises a little
 • ESV: {{c1::falls}} why? {{c1::higher contractility, more ejected}}
 • HR: rises ({{c1::70}} to {{c1::180}} beats/min)

Cardiac Failure at rest
• CO: {{c1::normal }}
• SV: {{c1::normal}} 
• EF: {{c1::a little low (~60%)}} 
• EDV: {{c1::high}} why?{{c1::reduced contractility}}
• ESV: {{c1::a little high }}
• HR: {{c1::normal}}

Cardiac Failure during exercise
• CO: only rises to ~11 L/min ({{c1::200%}}) 
• SV: rises from {{c1::80}} to {{c1::94}} mL {{c1::(low)}}
• EF: falls from {{c1::60}}% to ~{{c1::45}}% 
• EDV doubles, what does this lead to? {{c1::dilation of the ventricle}}
Heart rate doesn't increase as much, why? {{c1::Down-regulation of b1- adrenoceptors in the SA node occurs}}

What are two things a patient will complain about during excercise? {{c1::fatigue}} and {{c1::breathlessness}}

Why do cardiac failure patients complain of breathlessness?

As you know, there is a higher EDV in these patients, so it makes sense that ventricular pressure is higher. 

How might this have an effect on pulmonary circulation?

{{c1::• Decreased LAP-LVP pressure gradient so more volume being kept in LA, so LA pressure increases, increasing pulmonary vein and capillary pressure which leads to pulmonary congestion}}

Compensatory Mechanisms of the heart: (V12 or something)

1. Increased adrenergic activity with vasoconstriction leading to increase {{c1::TPR}}

We know that vasocontriction happens in arteries to mantiain MAP
But do the veins undergo constriction? {{c1::yes}} Why? {{c1::increases venous return, so increased EDV, so increased SV}}

What are the vasoconstrictive effects achived by?
{{c1::- increased SNA (sympathetic nerve stimulation) - elevated plasma angiotensin-II - elevated plasma endothelin-1}}


2. Increased extracellular fluid volume we've gone through this


3. Unequal Distribution of blood to organs

Normal CO {{c1::5.8}}l/min
Congestive Cardiac Failure CO {{c1::4.4}}l/min

• In cardiac failure, the limited cardiac output is preferentially distributed to:
 {{c1::- heart (coronary blood flow)
 - brain (cerebral blood flow)
 - skeletal muscle}} (3)

• Blood flow to the following organs is reduced:
 {{c1::- kidney (renal blood flow)
 - skin (cutaneous blood flow)

What is the fun colour related effect of this?{{c1::Since blood flow to the skin is reduced, cyanosis occurs in the peripheries, they turn blue}}

Left Heart Failure:
• Increased EDV 
• Increased EDP

How would this cause pulmonary oedema?{{c1::Increased capillary and venous pressure pushes fluid into the interstitial space}}

Right heart failure

{{c1::Ultrafiltration rate exceeds reabsorption + lymph flow, oedema in periphery}}

Jugular venous pulse
 • There are no valves between the venae cavae and the right atrium

When would right atrial pressure rise episodically?{{c1::holding breath, lifting weight, holding a note}}

When would right atrial pressure stay risen? {{c1::Right heart failure}}
Jugular venous pulse is easily seen in the these patients when they are supine (lying down)

What is Law of Laplace:{{c1::pressure=2 x tension x wall thickness  / radius}}

So will a dilated ventricle be more or less effective {{c1::less}}

Why? 1.{{c1::A dilated ventricle genrally acts higher up on a starling curve, meaning that the filling plateau is soon reachesd}}

2.{{c1::If muscle is overstretched cross bridges go to shit}}

Problems faced by the failing heart (systolic failure):

Dilation of the ventricle causes:
-{{c1::Contraction}} of heart muscle is less efficient
-{{c1::Reduced}} active tension
-Valves may become leaky, why? {{c1::Chambers dilate but valves stay same size}}

Reduced Contractility

High Cardiac workload due to high {{c1::afterload}}

Afterload:{{c1::- is the stress developed in the ventricular wall during ejection}}

• Increased afterload 
{{c1::-increase}} is cardiac work 
{{c1::-decrease}} in SV


In failing heart
• As {{c1::MAP}} must be maintained, the afterload on the failing heart is high 
• The failing ventricle, in which contractility is reduced, has to expend more energy (perform more work) on ejecting the same SV as the normal ventricle

How might this progress negatively?{{c1::Increased work exposes the ventricle to: -a mismatch between O2 consumption and O2 delivery -the risk of becoming ischaemic}}

Principles of treatment of cardiac failure (systolic failure)
The aims of treatment from a physiological point of view are: 
1. to reduce {{c1::cardiac work}}
2. to reduce the {{c1::excessive plasma volume and cardiac dilation }}
3. to improve {{c1::myocardial contractility}}

Reduce cardiac work 
• Cardiac work at rest can be reduce by 

- reducing arterial pressure (afterload) 
          - peripheral vasodilator: {{c1::a1-adrenoceptor blockade, Ca2+ antagonism }}
 
- reducing filling pressure (preload)
          - peripheral venodilator: {{c1::nitroprusside}}

How would using a venodilator reduce filling pressure?{{c1::blood returns slower as less pressure}}


Reduce blood pressure 
• {{c1::a1-adreno}}ceptor blocker 
• {{c1::ACE inhibitor}} (interrupt Ang II production) 
• {{c1::β-adrenoceptor}} blocker (reduce HR and contractility)

How would you reduced ventricular dilation?
{{c1::Reduction of plasma volume reduces ventricular filling}}

What drugs would ya use?{{c1::diuretic drugs (thiazides, frusamide) and ACE inhibitors}}

Do all cardiac failure patients recieve drugs to increase contractility? {{c1::no,Now restricted to patients waiting for heart transplantation}}

What drugs would you use
{{c1::A positive inotropic agent such as digoxin improves myocardial contractility - increased intracellular concentration of Ca2+ ions}}
